reviewText: Navy SEALS, 1990 filmThis movie begins at sea. An unarmed Navy helicopter is attacked when it goes to the aid of a burning ship at sea. Later we see a man laying on the beach, as if washed ashore. He later jumps off a bridge into the water. [Symbolism?] At the church pagers start beeping to recall the group. At an eastern Mediterranean port there is a reaction to the shooting down of that helicopter. The SEAL team rescues the survivors and neutralizes the enemy. Two men form a rear guard. There is plenty of action and gunfire; it is well orchestrated. Back in Washington top officials worry about those Stinger missiles. [Did the Reagan Administration give them away without forethought?] Back home the team relaxes at a golf course. You shouldn't park in a `No Parking' zone.SEAL Command has a plan to retrieve those missiles. This time they take the boat to their destination. Someone sees them. An explosion awakes the passengers. The team takes over the ship on the high seas, but find nothing. One man approaches a reporter to ask questions. We see their realistic training; only 10% pass the course. Will that journalist provide information? A Stinger in Spain shoots down an airplane. Washington picks a target, but he has been a source of information. They plan to "extract" him. The team jumps from an airplane into the sea, and goes ashore. Will things go as planned? Will Hawkins make a rash decision? There is sad news and a funeral. "A training accident?" They mourn at a bar. Hawkins acknowledges his mistake. Later they learn where those missiles are stored, and plan to destroy them in Beirut. A man will guide them to the site.They are armed with AK-47 rifles so their shots will not sound different. They find the Stingers and prepare an explosion to destroy them. The dawn brings activity and more shooting. The explosion causes the destruction of the building, it "pancakes" upon itself. [Was this an inspiration for others?] There is a car hijacking too. The team escapes to the seashore. Can they rendezvous with the submarine in time? Can they survive an attack? Then the submarine picks them from the sea for a happy ending. This is an interesting story. I think it runs on a little too long. Was this movie meant as advertising for Navy SEALS? Is there a subtle criticism about their actions in invading a foreign country?Why did those missiles get into the possession of terrorists? Watch "Charlie's War" for the answer.
Title: N/A

reviewText: But then, my tastes in movies have improved since I was fifteen. The plot is see through, and the dialogue seems to have been stolen from every Navy SEAL book they can find (more SEAL cliches than WWII movies). Sheen is as transparent as usual in the over-the-top 'badboy' SEAL, who any commander worth anything would have kicked off the Teams. Micheal Biehn and Bill Paxton (who only had a small part) are both excellent actors who just picked a bad movie (Biehn's SEAL role in The Rock is a much better portrayal). This movie came about after the SEALs came to the attention of the world, but a poor script, bad acting, and bad directing make this movie just horrible.
summary: I don't remember it being this bad

reviewText: I hadn't seen this movie since it first came out, so I bought a copy here on Amazon and after watching it, I quickly remembered why I was lukewarm on the film years ago. This is an action film that definitely fits the 1980s style of Hollywood action movies. In that respect, it's pretty good. A large portion of the film is actually dedicated to action scenes and operations. However, that's also part of the downside of the movie. There is very little character development or even plot development for that matter. The movie seems to be little more than a series of scenes in which the SEAL team flips between the US and missions in the Middle East, with no mention of the travel time between. Since the debut of this movie there have been so many movies, documentaries and books about these kinds of units and others that the movie seems kind of quaint and out-of-touch with reality. The supposedly Arabic venues don't seem too bad, but the Arabic actors are a bit cheesy compared to those in more current films, and as mentioned before, the SEAL aspect seems a bit contrived and unrealistic. However, if you can put those concerns aside, this is a fairly watchable film. The characters that make up the SEAL team are interesting and even quirky in some cases without going over the top and the Middle Eastern situations are just realistic enough to make that part of the movie seem plausible. If you like 1980s action films, this one is worth checking out.
summary: Watchable but paper thin in some regards
Title: N/A

reviewText: I didn't see this movie until 2014, so maybe I'm missing some of the 80's/90's context... but I was alive and watching other R rated movies then, so I feel like I'm justified in saying that this movie sorely lacks--mostly because it's confused.  Based on the (1) the subject matter and (2) the cast, it looks well-positioned to make a great, semi-serious, action bonanza.  However, based on (1) terrible direction, (2) flat, self-contradicting characters and (3) bad writing, it turns into a big boring slog.  It tries to jump between overly serious and awkwardly attempting humor at all the wrong times.  It's hard to put my finger on what is so dull about it, but here's one example:  At one point, a key character is wounded badly in the heat of battle.  It seems like if there was ever a time to create tension and excitement, this would be it, right?  The jokes and humor are for back at the barracks, right?  Wrong.  The barracks feature cheesy "serious" acting, and when a hero is badly shot in the heat of battle, the movie attempts strange humor by making a joke of how he gets "high" on morphine.  So as his teammates carry his bloody carcass, he's smiling and laughing.  This would be okay, but this movie feels like half the scene are from "Hot Shot" and the other half are from some really violent intense drama.  Just weird.  I wish they had chosen to either make it serious and dramatic or a big fun action romp.  It didn't work trying to do both.

reviewText: The U. S. fight against Islamic terrorism makes for an easy plot structure; they want to blow up Americans while the American commando teams try to stop them. It is also topical as Islamic terrorists are the current primary public exterior enemy. This story opens with a Navy SEAL team on the ground freeing a group of hostages. During the extrication they discover several crates of powerful Stinger anti-aircraft missiles. An attempt to destroy the missiles fails and the commander of the team makes the decision to leave rather than commit a heroic suicide.Some of their superiors object to this action and the pressure increases when a Stinger is used to shoot down a civilian aircraft. In an intense effort to discover the location of the missiles, Lt. Curran, the SEAL team leader, begins a relationship with a female reporter with contacts in the Middle East. After learning of the location, the team goes into Beirut and must fight its way in and out of the city.There is a lot of intense action, some humorous moments and some incredible stupidity committed by the Charlie Sheen character. In many ways he acts like the immature Charlie Sheen public persona rather than an efficient fighting man that is part of a small team of elite soldiers. In my opinion it would have been a better movie if that character had just been left out.
summary: A lot of intense action with some stupid moments inserted

reviewText: It took me three sittings to sit through most of Navy Seals, and I still dozed off through a few minutes of it.  Yes, boredum the movie's biggest problem.  This is by far the dullest action movie I've seen in years, maybe even of all-time.What's the plot?  Who cares?  It's just bare bones enough to string up some action sequences, but unfortunately, the action scenes smell of made-for-TV quality.  Heck, some of the stuff that's made-for-TV these days features better action (i.e. Band of Brothers).  Director Lewis Teague obviously doesn't know much more than the good old point-and-shoot method, meaning he's got no style or, for that matter, a sense of direction.  People shoot, get shot, and it's a basic, routine pattern that continues for all the gunfights.  There are no cool stunts, outrageous situations, or edgy tension during all these scenes.The way it is for me is that movies involving commando teams are rarely ever exciting, mainly because it's a bunch of tough guys who seem invincible, even when a couple of them get killed.  Oh, don't get me wrong, there are notable exceptions (such as the nail-biter Executive Decision), but Navy Seals sure isn't one of them.  The film never builds up any suspense because the villains never seem like a threat.  None of the bad guys are even the slightest bit menacing.  Already, at least half the movie's effectiveness is gone.But the "heroes" are just as lame and uninteresting.  For these parts, acting's what you'd expect.  Charlie Sheen plays himself, annoying and idiotic as usual.  Michael Biehn is the tough-as-nails commander, a role he can do in his sleep, though he plays the part so straight he might just induce some sleep in the viewers.  Nobody else makes an impression, not even the usually funny Bill Paxton.I don't have much more to say about Navy Seals, other than its third-rate, silly crap that fails on every intended level.  It's dull plot and premise won't make this an enjoyable movie to trash in a crowd, and its boring execution will put a lot of viewers to sleep.  Definitely one of the nadirs of awful modern action filmmaking.1/2 out of *****
Title: N/A

reviewText: The lineup of cast members are really impressive, minus Charlie Sheen, who again makes it to the script's boat motor and pulls and pulls the string, breaking it. My two fav actors are Biehn and Paxton (real life friends) and I must say that this flick was not worthy of the cast, especially these two. Joanne Whaley, Cyril O'Reiley, and Rick Rossovich, also good actors, were wasted. Some scenes, like the debut of their skills, during the rescue of the remaining 2 American G.I.'s, and the skydive to the coast, were great. Too many of the other action scenes were not believable or tactically true. Biehn is always on the ball, although his dialouge and scrpit matter  fail to let him shine. Dennis Ranbert, too bad he was knocked off by Sheen's carelessness. And then Hawkin's is still allowed to be on the team? Is the script stupid or what?  I vote for a remake, but with the same cast-I know they're older, bu so what. And the lines by Sheen? He's not THAT bad...and it's not his fault: it's the scriptwriter and producers! Sheen just seems to eat up the dialouge like a dinner-he really seems to be having fun with the garbage can script.Biehn: "Cool off!"Sheen: "You should see me when I'm hot!"Rescue the cast and put this NAVY adventure in a kiddie pool with water guns.
summary: Great cast gets a lousy script - needs to be remade
Title: N/A

reviewText: Navy Seals are sent on a rescue mission after a helicopter crew is captured by terrorists.  The terrorists just start killing hostages as the SEALs attack and rescue the balance of the hostages.  They actually find the leader of the terrorist but they believe that he is a hostage sailor from another country and let him go.While leaving the terrorist's base they find a cache of stinger missiles and while one of the SEALs want to go back and destroy them the mission commander tells them to leave...While this movie has a lot of action and continuous fight scenes on multiple missions I found the movies premise to be farfetched.  They spend multiple missions trying to find, destroy or capture the stinger missiles that they literally had in their hands on the first mission.  The plot is rather weak on that part of the movie but the action and fight scenes are pretty good.  They don't even ask for an air strike to destroy a cache of lethal missiles.As an entertainment movie it is a four star ranking based on action and introducing the SEALs.  On some issues I just really wonder if the real SEALs would have behaved in the same way as depicted in the movie.It is still worth watching as an action film with some good actors in it.

reviewText: Sixteen years after this was made, it is sort of amusing to see what "someone in Hollywood" thought would be a great morale booster in terms of displaying our military capabilities. Now that we know the reality of the situation of dealing with terrorists abroad, the flimsy premises of this tawdry little film seem even more ridiculous. But - at its core - it was an idiotic film then, and an even more idiotic film now.
summary: Absurd in the light of reality

reviewText: I really liked it. I liked the first action scene to the team best. I think the story was good. I believe i saw parts or the whole filmmany years ago on tv. I didn`t expect it to be so good, so i was suprised. I like this kind of film.Picture Quality: 4/5I think it looked good. I see it hashas only a MPEG-2 encode on a 25 GB disc, but i still think it`s good.Yes, it would have looked better using a encode like MPEG-4 and 50 GB disc, but i don`t expect them to usethat and re-release it again. I think the colours and details looks pretty sharp and detailed. It was goodenough for me.Audio Quality: 4/5I think the DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 had mixed results. I think the first action scene in the film, where they usethose MP5`s(i believe), sounded best. The gunfire effects had good bass. In the end shootout where they usedAK-47`s, i think the gunfire effects lacked bass. They should had more bass. The explosions coming out of mysubwoofer in this film, impressed me. The music and dialog was good coming from the Center speaker.The Surround speakers was used for some music and of course used in the action scenes. I heard bullets andemptied shells, and such in the surround speakers. That Sniper rifle that is used perhaps 2 times in this film,was very impressive. I think it had pretty deep bass. I was very suprised by that. Great.film: 4.5/5Overall: 4/5

reviewText: Any movie [almost] that gives an idea of what our guys go through should be appreciated.As to characters, Michael Biehn and Charlie Sheen did very well - if you object to some of it, go back to the writer and director.Sorry but I missed recognizing Bill Paxton but loved the action [am I mistaken or was the DVD missing some parts that were in the video?]Charlie Sheen's character - well there is almost one in every movie to provide conflict.  A character that must learn by his mistakes - a bit of a smart aleck.If it does nothing more that encourage you to pray for our guys in combat, then the movie was a sucess.  At the very least it is just entertainment if you don't take it too personally.Hopefully another one just like it will be that much better as we get into better tech.  Enjoy, it is not that bad.

reviewText: Amazing...simply amazing.  This film deserves 5 stars simply becase it is the first movie I've ever seen that I just couldn't finish watching.  Maybe it was the playfully fun "Boys Are Back In Town" golfing scene  (which may be THE most realistic scene in the film, mind you!) or maybe it  was just the originality of Charlie Sheen's maverick hot-dogging  character(what a charmer!).  You tell me.I put this right up there with  Clint Eastwood's "Heartbreak Ridge" for realism, fun, and good  characters.  This is just a great time no matter which way you slice it.  Get it now before it sells out!

reviewText: Ah, NAVY SEALS, a fond memory from teenage days, VHS tapes, hockey hair, chips, lots of soda and what not. Seeing it back then you'd probably tell your guys, "Oh, we HAVE to rent this! It's with that guy from the Terminator and that guy from Platoon!" That not having to be a good thing escaped you back in the day.This movie now feels quite dated, not to mention perverse. It reminds you of how Sheen a little later would make Hot Shots and realise this was a joke on Top Gun, and with Part Deux, a joke on Rambo. NAVY SEALS can be forgiven not getting the joke, it can't be forgiven smelling like Reagans big boy diapers. The other day I saw a short documentary on the excellent Dirty Harry box set (blu-ray), discussing wether or not Dirty Harry is fascist. That reminded me of how the fascist word (which is thrown around too much these days), was thrown at Starship Troopers a few years back. But that was a film with tongue in cheek, and was done so intentionally. So, most people with a fleeting knowledge should have got it. This film NAVY SEALS, is NOT tongue in cheek. If a tongue came near a cheek here, it would be to demonstrate some latent male homophobia, or perhaps to demonstrate something lude to women.That leads me to my main critizism of this this film now. It feels constructed for our benefit, like a fascist society NAVY recruitment film. All the jokes, all the action are done with robotic presission, with no room for afterthought, or gut feeling.Made in an era where muslim arabs were still mostly something that got beat up by Israelis, and had to be watched closely so the didn't ally themselves with the evil Soviets, much have changed. Now the muslim arabs ARE the enemy to a large extent, partly because of geopolitics, because british and french accented bad guys are starting to seem silly, but mostly because some of them have handed Hollywood the enemy they couldn't have dreamt up in their worst nighmares, NAVY SEALS can be seen a historic by-product, and as such, is best seen with any knowledge of the World in general turned down to a minimum.If you do that, you'll have to contend with Charlie Sheens blood thirsty goofball, the baffling conducts of Bichael Biehns character, and a lot of fun cameradery set to poodle haired 80s hard rock in a odly Golden Girls like enviroment.
